hypothesis.name: Optimal Tilt for Midday Sun
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt angle of approximately 30° is often optimal for maximizing solar energy capture during midday when the sun is highest in the sky.

hypothesis.name: Maximize Morning Energy
hypothesis.rationale: Setting the azimuth to 90° (east) with a tilt of 45° can enhance energy capture during the morning hours.

hypothesis.name: Evening Energy Capture
hypothesis.rationale: An azimuth of 270° (west) with a tilt of 20° may optimize energy production in the evening when the sun sets.

hypothesis.name: Balanced System Capacity
hypothesis.rationale: A moderate system capacity of 8 kW with a tilt of 35° and azimuth of 180° can provide a balanced approach to energy production throughout the day.

hypothesis.name: High Capacity for Optimal Output
hypothesis.rationale: Maximizing system capacity to 20 kW with a tilt of 25° and azimuth of 150° may yield high energy output, especially in regions with consistent sunlight.

hypothesis.name: High Tilt and Optimal Azimuth
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt of 55° with an azimuth of 160° is expected to maximize energy capture based on the highest observed outputs.

hypothesis.name: Exploring Higher Tilt Angles
hypothesis.rationale: Testing a tilt of 60° with a similar azimuth of 160° may further enhance energy production, given the trend of higher outputs with increased tilt.

hypothesis.name: Moderate Tilt with High Capacity
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt of 45° and azimuth of 150° with a system capacity of 20 kW may balance energy capture throughout the day.

hypothesis.name: Lower Tilt for Morning Capture
hypothesis.rationale: Testing a tilt of 30° with an azimuth of 90° may still yield some energy during morning hours, despite lower overall performance.

hypothesis.name: High Capacity with Low Tilt
hypothesis.rationale: Exploring a tilt of 20° with a system capacity of 20 kW and azimuth of 180° may provide insights into the lower bounds of effective configurations.

hypothesis.name: High Tilt and Optimal Azimuth
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt of 65° with an azimuth of 160° is expected to maximize energy capture based on the highest observed outputs.
